resources.string: If you enjoy using this app, would you mind taking a moment to rate it? It won\'t take more than a minute. Thanks for your support!

Welcome to the world of musical cryptography.

In the early 1900s two master music composers arranged the English alphabet into seven columns.

ABCDEFG
HIJKLMN
OPQRSTU
VWXYZ

This became known as the French musical cryptogram cipher. 

Today, we hope to present to you an new instrument in composing music. It is a stepping stone towards a new way to enjoy melodies you create and personalize them by entering names of your favorite people, places, and things.

 It is also a new tool to assist budding composers realizing themselves as actual musicians whose own names can be heard as a ringtone. It teaches memorization for identifying how particular notes sound.

Step one: Tap the field of play.

Step two: Choose an instrument.

Step three: Tap Play to hear it repeat.

The setting icon on the right allows you to modify your melody:
• 47 instruments
• 89 scales
• 12 key changes
• 3 drum patterns/live drums/none
• 5 bass octaves
• 5 treble octaves
• 60-360 words per minute

The menu on the left allows you to:

• save a melody
• load saved melodies
• set as phone ringtone
• set as notification ringtone
• set as alarm ringtone

The keymap displays which notes play for which letters. This also allows you to "solo" words over your creations.

The randomizer allows you to add personalized words into a randomly created unique song.

That's it!

Stacking letters, including actual note names (ABCDEFG) play chords. 

Here is a list of current instruments available to draw out and sustain the note by adding dots (...) after any character:

• Rock Organ
• Church Organ
• Accordion
• Distortion Guitar
• Violin
• Viola
• Tremelo Strings
• String Ensemble 1
• String Ensemble 2
• Trombone

• Flute

• Shakuhatchi
• Whistle
• Lead (square)
• Pad (new age)
• Pad (warm)
• Bag Pipe
• Fiddle
• Shanai

Example:

Copy (below) into the field of play and set it to the key of G and in the MAJOR scale. Set the instrument to STRING ENSEMBLE 2. 

 T..X...Z...............Q.R..............
V..........W..........V..........S..........
T..........S..........T..........Q..........
Q..........Q..........R..........O..........
M..........J..........K..........H..........
F..........C..........D..........A..........

You will find incidentally occurring words as you become more familiar with your new instrument.

Wait, what is Musician's Mode? 

To hear a single letter as a chord, here is its current specification.
